comments.raw_text:
User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10.6; rv:2.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/4.0
Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10.6; rv:2.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/4.0

I have 4 tabs set up for my home pages. Clicking [home] once brings up those 4 tabs. Click it again and I have 7 tabs. Click it again and I have 10 tabs...

Reproducible: Always

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open multiple tabs on different addresses.
2. Open Firefox Preferences and select [Use Current Page] in the Startup section.
3. Close Preferences
4. Click [Home] button
5. Click [Home] button again
Actual Results:  
Numerous copies of the same pages on different tabs
comments.text:
User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10.6; rv:2.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/4.0
Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10.6; rv:2.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/4.0

I have 4 tabs set up for my home pages. Clicking [home] once brings up those 4 tabs. Click it again and I have 7 tabs. Click it again and I have 10 tabs...

Reproducible: Always

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open multiple tabs on different addresses.
2. Open Firefox Preferences and select [Use Current Page] in the Startup section.
3. Close Preferences
4. Click [Home] button
5. Click [Home] button again
Actual Results:  
Numerous copies of the same pages on different tabs
comments.creator: paul.turnbull@yahoo.co.uk
comments.author: paul.turnbull@yahoo.co.uk

comments.creator: vlad.ghetiu@softvision.ro
comments.raw_text: This is the intended behavior. One of the four home pages will always be opened in the focus tab, while the remaining three home pages will be opened in new tabs, resulting 3 new tabs every time you press the home button
comments.text: This is the intended behavior. One of the four home pages will always be opened in the focus tab, while the remaining three home pages will be opened in new tabs, resulting 3 new tabs every time you press the home button
comments.author: vlad.ghetiu@softvision.ro

comments.raw_text:
(In reply to comment #1)
> This is the intended behavior.

Hum, I have in mind that this is *not* the expected behavior. But I'm unable to find the bug I was thinking about.
